title: If I waive my wife's financial disclosures , will I be giving up my right to receive spousal support?
question: The court is telling me to do the form to waive her financial disclosures, then do the form to request a trial.
answers:
No. The court- you don't say in what way "the court" is "telling" you this--seems to be saying let them sort out the issues.

See "Mutual Waiver Of Final Declaration: On specified conditions, the parties may stipulate to a mutual waiver of the final declaration of disclosure requirements. But that waiver does not excuse the parties' compliance with their underlying statutory disclosure obligations. [See Ca Fam ยง 2105(d)]"

http://www.kinseylaw.com/clientserv2/famlawservices/disclosure/disclosure.html

One thing has nothing to do with the other.

The disclosures are required so that people can see "what's on the table." It is a way to try and keep the parties honest, and it is a way to avoid later claims that someone "didn't know about" an asset or debt. (Among other things.)

Your right to receive spousal support is a separate matter from disclosure of assets and debts. The only thing that disclosures do that has any bearing on the issue of spousal support is that they are supposed to include an Income and Expense Declaration, which is helpful in deciding if spousal support should be awarded (and how much). Not having received this information does not negate the right to receive support, it only makes it harder for the court to make a decision.

If the court is "telling you" to waive her disclosures, it is not really *telling you* but is probably *strongly suggesting to you* that without your spouse's cooperation and participation in the process, the only way that you could terminate your marriage would be to waive the receipt of the disclosures from your spouse and set the matter for default. You do not have to do this, but without your wife's cooperation, it truly is the only way to finish.

And, doing so, as I say, does not waive your right to receive spousal support. That requires a separate, specific waiver.

You cannot waive the preliminary declaration of disclosure. You can waive the final declaration of disclosure and move forward towards trial or settlement. You are not waiving your right to spousal support but what you are doing is saying I do not need an updated schedule of assets and debts outlining what she has and what I have and giving my estimation of the value or the actual value of the assets and the current debt, plus supporting documentation on the FL-142 Form. Best of luck with moving forward with your divorce. If you have trouble, seek help from your local self-help center or seek help from a local lawyer referral service to see if you qualify for pro-bono assistance.
